items.title: Seek offset exceeds file size
items.body:
## Overview

Seek offset exceeds file size when decoding the attached file.

## Expected behavior

When seeking with SEEK_SET, the offset should not be larger than the file size.

## Actual behavior

Seed offset exceeds file size when decoding the attached file.

## Investigation

Python's builtin `FileIO` won't throw an exception when seeking with offset > file size. Thus, there is no error when decoding using the builtin `open()`. However I am using a customized io in my application. That's why I found this issue. I believe this is a bug and should not be ignored.

## Reproduction

Use the following code.

```python
import io
import logging
import sys
import av


logger = logging.getLogger('pyav-test')


class File(io.FileIO):
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.full_size = self.seek(0, 2)
        self.seek(0, 0)

    def seek(self, offset, whence=0):
        logger.warning('seek: offset: %d, whence: %d', offset, whence)
        pos = super().seek(offset, whence)
        logger.warning('pos: %d', pos)
        logger.warning('tell: %d', pos)
        if whence == 0 and offset > self.full_size:
            raise Exception('Illegal seek')
        return pos


in_file = File(sys.argv[1], 'r')
out_file = open('out.pcm', 'wb')
resampler = av.AudioResampler(format='fltp', layout='mono', rate=16000)
container = av.open(in_file)
stream = next(s for s in container.streams if s.type == 'audio')

for packet in container.demux(stream):
    try:
        for frame in packet.decode():
            frame.pts = None
            out_frame = resampler.resample(frame)
            if out_frame is not None:
                plane = out_frame.planes[0]
                nbytes = 4 * out_frame.samples
                with memoryview(plane) as m:
                    l = 0
                    while l < nbytes:
                        l += out_file.write(m[l:nbytes])

    except av.InvalidDataError as e:
        sys.stderr.write(f'{e}\n')
```

The terminal log is in the attached archive.

## Versions

- OS: Ubuntu 20.04
- PyAV runtime:
```
PyAV v8.0.2
git origin: git@github.com:PyAV-Org/PyAV
git commit: v8.0.2
library configuration: --disable-doc --disable-static --enable-fontconfig --enable-gmp --enable-gnutls --enable-gpl --enable-libaom --enable-libass --enable-libbluray --enable-libdav1d --enable-libfreetype --enable-libmp3lame --enable-libopencore-amrnb --enable-libopencore-amrwb --enable-libopenjpeg --enable-libopus --enable-libspeex --enable-libtheora --enable-libtwolame --enable-libvorbis --enable-libwavpack --enable-libx264 --enable-libx265 --enable-libxml2 --enable-libxvid --enable-lzma --enable-shared --enable-version3 --enable-zlib --prefix=/tmp/vendor
library license: GPL version 3 or later
libavcodec     58. 54.100
libavdevice    58.  8.100
libavfilter     7. 57.100
libavformat    58. 29.100
libavutil      56. 31.100
libswresample   3.  5.100
libswscale      5.  5.100
```
- PyAV build: pypi version
- FFmpeg:
```
ffmpeg version 4.2.2-1ubuntu1 Copyright (c) 2000-2019 the FFmpeg developers
built with gcc 9 (Ubuntu 9.3.0-3ubuntu1)
configuration: --prefix=/usr --extra-version=1ubuntu1 --toolchain=hardened --libdir=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu --incdir=/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu --arch=amd64 --enable-gpl --disable-stripping --enable-avresample --disable-filter=resample --enable-avisynth --enable-gnutls --enable-ladspa --enable-libaom --enable-libass --enable-libbluray --enable-libbs2b --enable-libcaca --enable-libcdio --enable-libcodec2 --enable-libflite --enable-libfontconfig --enable-libfreetype --enable-libfribidi --enable-libgme --enable-libgsm --enable-libjack --enable-libmp3lame --enable-libmysofa --enable-libopenjpeg --enable-libopenmpt --enable-libopus --enable-libpulse --enable-librsvg --enable-librubberband --enable-libshine --enable-libsnappy --enable-libsoxr --enable-libspeex --enable-libssh --enable-libtheora --enable-libtwolame --enable-libvidstab --enable-libvorbis --enable-libvpx --enable-libwavpack --enable-libwebp --enable-libx265 --enable-libxml2 --enable-libxvid --enable-libzmq --enable-libzvbi --enable-lv2 --enable-omx --enable-openal --enable-opencl --enable-opengl --enable-sdl2 --enable-libdc1394 --enable-libdrm --enable-libiec61883 --enable-nvenc --enable-chromaprint --enable-frei0r --enable-libx264 --enable-shared

items.title: How to use pyav to decode a live stream of raw H.264 data?
items.body:
## Overview

The data was received by socket ,with no more shell , they are pure I P B frames begin with NAL Header(something like 00 00 00 01),  how to decode them frame by frame right after it was received (after got the first P frame). 


## Expected behavior

 I want to feed data to a sustaining decoder which can remember the previous P frame , so after feeding one B frame, the decoder return a decoded video frame.


## Actual behavior
My code will play the video but with a 3~4 seconds delay. 

Traceback:
Here is some key code.
```
#read thread... read until get a key frame, then make a new io.BytesIO() to store the new data.
rawFrames = io.BytesIO()
while flag_get_keyFrame:()
    ....
    content= socket.recv(2048)
    rawFrames.write(content)
    ....

#decode thread... decode content between two key frames
....
rawFrames.seek(0)
container = av.open(rawFrames)
for packet in container.demux():
    for frame in packet.decode():
        self.frames.append(frame)
....
```


## Investigation

I have searched for solution, but nothing seems to work.


## Research

I have done the following:

- [x] Checked the [PyAV documentation](https://pyav.org/docs)
- [x] Searched on [Google](https://www.google.com/search?q=pyav+how+do+I+foo)
- [x] Searched on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/search?q=pyav)

## Additional context

items.title: How do I FOO?
items.body:
## Overview

I tried to create a video encoder to get a h264 steam,while pyav always reports '[libx264] dimensions not set'.

## Expected behavior

It should return the encoder with right arguments given.
I use this to test my own mp4 mux library.

## Actual behavior

I have confirmed that argments given are right,but it still can't create the encoder

Traceback:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "d:/programworkspace/research/reserch_magewell/RSH_VPN/SSH_GIT/magewellsdkv3/test_codes/AVCapture/mp4filesave.py", line 58, in <module>
    test()
  File "d:/programworkspace/research/reserch_magewell/RSH_VPN/SSH_GIT/magewellsdkv3/test_codes/AVCapture/mp4filesave.py", line 55, in test
    t_encoder.create_mp4('1.mp4',1920,1080,166667)
  File "d:/programworkspace/research/reserch_magewell/RSH_VPN/SSH_GIT/magewellsdkv3/test_codes/AVCapture/mp4filesave.py", line 26, in create_mp4
    self.create_video_encoder()
  File "d:/programworkspace/research/reserch_magewell/RSH_VPN/SSH_GIT/magewellsdkv3/test_codes/AVCapture/mp4filesave.py", line 43, in create_video_encoder
    t_b_ret = self.m_ctx_video_codec.open()
  File "av\codec\context.pyx", line 253, in av.codec.context.CodecContext.open
  File "av\codec\context.pyx", line 275, in av.codec.context.CodecContext.open
  File "av\error.pyx", line 336, in av.error.err_check
av.error.ValueError: [Errno 22] Invalid argument; last error log: [libx264] dimensions not set
```

## Investigation

I cheked the params and check the code of ffmpeg

## Research

I have done the following:

- [x] Checked the [PyAV documentation](https://pyav.org/docs)
- [x] Searched on [Google](https://www.google.com/search?q=pyav+how+do+I+foo)
- [x] Searched on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/search?q=pyav)

## Additional context

Here is my test code.

```python
import av
from av import format,codec
from av.video.codeccontext import *
import av.video.format
import fractions

class CMWMp4Save(object):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.m_video_codec = 0
        self.m_ctx_video_codec = 0
        self.m_audio_codec = 0
        self.m_ctx_audio_codec = 0
        self.m_n_cx = 1920
        self.m_n_cy = 1080
        self.m_fps = 60
    
    def create_mp4(self,
        filename,
        cx,
        cy,
        frame_dur):
        self.m_n_cx = cx
        self.m_n_cy = cy
        self.m_fps = 10000000/frame_dur
        self.create_video_encoder()

    def destory_mp4(self):
        pass

    def create_video_encoder(self):
        self.m_video_codec = codec.Codec('h264','w')
        print(self.m_video_codec)
        self.m_ctx_video_codec = self.m_video_codec.create()
        self.m_ctx_video_codec.bit_rate = 400000
        self.m_ctx_video_codec.width = self.m_n_cx
        self.m_ctx_video_codec.height = self.m_n_cy
        self.m_ctx_video_codec.framerate = fractions.Fraction(int(self.m_fps),1)
        self.m_ctx_video_codec.gop_size = 60
        self.m_ctx_video_codec.format = av.VideoFormat('nv12')
        print(self.m_video_codec.frame_rates)
        t_b_ret = self.m_ctx_video_codec.open()
        if t_b_ret == True:
            print('create video codec successfully')
        else:
            print('create video codec failed')

t_encoder = CMWMp4Save()

def test():
    global t_encoder
    print('test')
    t_encoder.create_mp4('1.mp4',1920,1080,166667)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    test()
```

items.title: VideoCodecContext.encode() not working with h264_nvmpi
items.body:
## Overview

I successfully built ffmpeg 4.2.2 from deb-src with `h264_nvmpi` HW encoder and decoder support using [this library](https://github.com/jocover/jetson-ffmpeg) and it seems installing PyAV 8.0 with `pip3 install av --no-binary av` picked the codec up from the shared libs.

## Expected behavior

We should be able to use NVENC & NVDEC codecs for HW accelerated support.

## Actual behavior

The `av.VideoCodecContext.encode()` function returns empty array instead of bytes.

Traceback:
```
self.codec = av.CodecContext.create("h264_nvmpi", "w")
self.codec.width = frame.width
self.codec.height = frame.height
self.codec.pix_fmt = "yuv420p"
self.codec.time_base = fractions.Fraction(1, MAX_FRAME_RATE)
self.codec.options = {
    "profile": "baseline",
    "level": "3.1",
}

packages = self.codec.encode(frame)
print(len(packages)) # = 0
```
Debug prints:
```
<av.VideoFrame #0, pts=0 yuyv422 640x480 at 0x7f9285c2b8>

0
b''
```

items.title: Creating UDP broadcast socket with audio packets (client/server sides)
items.body:
Hi, I have to create a audio streaming system which captures audio from my PC mic and sends UDP packets to WebRTC peers (I am using aiortc). What I have done so far has been creating a peer with a MediaPlayer (which relies on PyAV) to capture the audio from the microphone, but when another peer connects to the "room" the PyAV library tells me that the ALSA is busy. So I was thinking to instead or creating instances of players which capture the mic audio directly, to have a single audio capture server which broadcasts in localhost UDP packets, then several UDP clients are open to catch those packets (something like av.open("udp://localhost:6000")). My question is if there is a better approach to do this task. And if this is actually the only one solution, how to create the server and client sides:
- The PyAV server captures the audio from the microphone and sends UDP packets.
- The PyAV clients connects to the local port and decode the sent audio UDP packets.

items.title: Incorrect audio length of AAC file
items.body:
**It looks like I am doing transcode, but I AM NOT.**
```python
import av
import soundfile as sf

data, sample_rate = sf.read('something.wav')
n_samples = data.shape[0]
n_channels = data.shape[1]

container = av.open('test.aac', 'w')
stream = container.add_stream('aac', rate=sample_rate)

stream.open()
time_base = stream.codec_context.time_base
frame_size = stream.codec_context.frame_size

stride = frame_size * n_channels

data = data.reshape(1, -1)
for i in range(0, n_samples * n_channels, stride):
    frame = av.AudioFrame.from_ndarray(data[:, i:i+stride], 'dbl')
    frame.sample_rate = sample_rate
    frame.time_base = time_base
    frame.pts = i // n_channels

    container.mux(stream.encode(frame))

container.mux(stream.encode())
container.close()
```

I am using Numpy to generate audio file and want to use PyAV to encode as AAC file. ~~It is the same format as I open the file with PySoundFile.~~

The file could be generated but my player shows incorrect audio length. I have a 5 second audio, but it shows the AAC file form PyAV is 51 seconds long.

Btw, if I remove the two lines shown in below, 
```
    frame.time_base = time_base
    frame.pts = i // n_channels
```
ffmpeg will complain `Encoder did not produce proper pts, making some up.`

items.title: Unable to import av installed from binary on Mac OSX High Sierra
items.body:
## Overview

When trying to use PyAV (i.e. `import av`) on Mac OSX High Sierra (10.13.6), I get a `Symbol not found: ____chkstk_darwin` from dlopen. It seems like a few others have been bitten by this such as [cryptography](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/5215).

## Expected behavior

Importing `av` to just work:
```console
(venv) samn@RD011386 $ pip install av
Looking in indexes: https://pypi.org/simple, https://artifactory.virt.ch.bbc.co.uk/artifactory/api/pypi/ap-python/simple
Collecting av
  Using cached av-8.0.1-cp36-cp36m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl (19.1 MB)
Installing collected packages: av
Successfully installed av-8.0.1
(venv) sam@RD011386 $ python3 -c "import av"
(venv) sam@RD011386 $
```

## Actual behavior

Importing `av` fails with a `Symbol not found` error.

```console
(venv) samn@RD011386 $ pip install av
Looking in indexes: https://pypi.org/simple, https://artifactory.virt.ch.bbc.co.uk/artifactory/api/pypi/ap-python/simple
Collecting av
  Using cached av-8.0.1-cp36-cp36m-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl (19.1 MB)
Installing collected packages: av
Successfully installed av-8.0.1
(venv) sam@RD011386 $ python3 -c "import av"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/samn/local-projects/tenpercent/rd-hot-desk-radio-studio/rd-recording/split_shows/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/av/__init__.py", line 9, in <module>
    from av._core import time_base, pyav_version as __version__, library_versions
ImportError: dlopen(/Users/samn/local-projects/tenpercent/rd-hot-desk-radio-studio/rd-recording/split_shows/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/av/_core.cpython-36m-darwin.so, 2): Symbol not found: ____chkstk_darwin
  Referenced from: /Users/samn/local-projects/tenpercent/rd-hot-desk-radio-studio/rd-recording/split_shows/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/av/.dylibs/libavutil.56.31.100.dylib (which was built for Mac OS X 10.15)
  Expected in: /usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib
 in /Users/samn/local-projects/tenpercent/rd-hot-desk-radio-studio/rd-recording/split_shows/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/av/.dylibs/libavutil.56.31.100.dylib
(venv) sam@RD011386 $
```

Build report:
https://gist.github.com/samdbmg/bdaf66534bbf2b2ab9353f30f0ffcf7a


## Investigation

I've tested this with `pip install av --no-binary av` which works fine, so I think it only affects the binary wheels. Some reading of related issues suggests the ABI changed between High Sierra (10.13) and Catalina (10.15) but setting the CFLAG `-mmacosx-version-min=10.x` will force backwards compatibility to that version (from https://github.com/pyca/infra/pull/275) 

## Reproduction

1. Get a Mac running High Sierra
2. Run `python3 -m virtualenv venv && . venv/bin/activate && pip install av && python3 -c "import av"`
3. Observe the last command fails with a stacktrace

## Versions

- OS: macOS 10.13.6

items.title: In-place av.Packet creation without copying the input buffer
items.body:
The use case is simply to forward an incoming video stream through a private protocol to a cloud streaming service on AWS using an EC2 instance.

The `av.Packet` is created to hold raw H.264 frames for computing some time info but it is noticed that the CPU load becomes so high to overwhelm average EC2 instances when the source streaming bitrate is > 10Mbps.

Looking into `av/packet.pyx`, it seems like the input is always copied even if its from some Python buffer object such as the `memoryview` as follows. The `self.update(source)` eventually calls `memcpy` to copy the input buffer in the `Buffer` class.

```cython
        if source is not None:
            self.update(source)
            # TODO: Hold onto the source, and copy its pointer
            # instead of its data.
            # self.source = source
```

We compare the CPU load without creating `av.Packet` every time and found the CPU load could decrease to one third or lower. Therefore, we are really wondering if it is possible to avoid the copying in `av.Packet` as commented in the source code.
Any ideas?

items.title: How do I concat segments/chunks without framerate/duration problems?
items.body:
**IMPORTANT:** Be sure to replace all template sections {{ like this }} or your issue may be discarded.


## Overview

I am trying to use pyav to handle many steps in a project:
* [*] split file in data chunks and store them in database. Done.
* [] filter/encode chunks stored in database. To do.
* [] concat chunks from database back to a file. WIP...

I can not manage to make the concat part works.
My current code gives me a not correctly playable file.

Here is the code:

```python
def concat_file(source: str, destination: str, start: int = 0):
    # handle file pathes
    source_path = Path(source).expanduser()
    destination_path = Path(destination).expanduser()

    # init vars
    index = start
    output = None
    in_to_out = {}
    last_chunk_ts = {}
    first_chunk = True
    last_packet = {}

    # for each chunk...
    while Path(str(source_path) % index).exists():
        input_ = av.open(str(source_path) % index)
        if index == start:
            input_format_code = get_format_code(input_.format, source_path.suffix.strip('.'))
            # issue #600, so open file with python
            # output = av.open(str(destination_path).encode('utf-8'), 'w', format=input_format_code)
            output_file = open(str(destination_path), 'wb')
            output = av.open(output_file, 'w', format=input_format_code)

            # create stream map
            for in_stream in input_.streams:
                if in_stream.codec:
                    in_to_out[in_stream.index] = output.add_stream(template=in_stream)
        print("concat chunk {} to file {}".format(str(source_path) % index, str(destination_path)))

        chunk_offset = {}
        # for each packet...
        for i, packet in enumerate(input_.demux(*input_.streams)):
            # We need to skip the "flushing" packets that `demux` generates.
            if packet.dts is None:
                continue
            if packet.stream.index in in_to_out:
                # packet for the output stream now
                packet.stream = in_to_out[packet.stream.index]

                if not first_chunk:
                    # if first packet in chunk for a stream
                    if packet.stream.index not in chunk_offset:
                        # store start offset
                        chunk_offset[packet.stream.index] = {'dts': packet.dts, 'pts': packet.pts}
                        print('chunk_offset=', chunk_offset)
                        print("start dts at", packet.dts - chunk_offset[packet.stream.index]['dts'] + \
                                                         last_chunk_ts[packet.stream.index]['dts'] + last_packet[packet.stream.index].duration)
                        print("start pts at", packet.pts - chunk_offset[packet.stream.index]['pts'] + \
                                                         last_chunk_ts[packet.stream.index]['pts'] + last_packet[packet.stream.index].duration)

                    packet.dts = packet.dts - chunk_offset[packet.stream.index]['dts'] + \
                                 last_chunk_ts[packet.stream.index]['dts'] + last_packet[packet.stream.index].duration
                    packet.pts = packet.pts - chunk_offset[packet.stream.index]['pts'] + \
                                 last_chunk_ts[packet.stream.index]['pts'] + last_packet[packet.stream.index].duration

                # mux packet in output container
                output.mux(packet)
                # print(packet)
                # print("muxed packet from chunk {} to file {}".format(str(source_path) % index, str(destination_path)))
                last_packet[packet.stream.index] = packet

            last_chunk_ts[packet.stream.index] = {'dts': packet.dts, 'pts': packet.dts, 'duration': packet.duration}
            # print("last_chunk_ts of chunk", last_chunk_ts)

        input_.close()
        first_chunk = False
        index += 1
    for stream in output.streams:
        print(stream.rate, stream.duration, stream.time_base)
    output.close()
```

## Expected behavior

The concatenated file should have this parameters (chunks concatenated with ffmpeg concat):
```
Duration: 00:02:23.44, start: 0.000000, bitrate: 1683 kb/s
    Stream #0:0(und): Video: h264 (High) (avc1 / 0x31637661), yuv420p, 1280x692, 1532 kb/s, 25 fps, 25 tbr, 12800 tbn, 50 tbc (default)

```

## Actual behavior

My code create a not correctly playable file with this parameters:
```
Duration: 11:18:24.64, start: 0.000000, bitrate: 5 kb/s
    Stream #0:0(und): Video: h264 (High) (avc1 / 0x31637661), yuv420p, 1280x692, 5 kb/s, 0.09 fps, 25 tbr, 12800 tbn, 50 tbc (default)
```
## Investigation

Use ffprobe heavily to verify the contiguous dts an pts at split points. Seems good.

## Research

I have done the following:

- [ *] Checked the [PyAV documentation](http://docs.mikeboers.com/pyav/stable/)
- [* ] Searched on [Google](https://www.google.com/search?q=pyav+how+do+I+foo)
- [ ] Searched on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/search?q=pyav)
- [* ] Looked through [old GitHub issues](https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/issues?&q=is%3Aissue)
- [ ] Asked on [PyAV Gitter](https://gitter.im/mikeboers/PyAV)
- [ ] ... and waited 72 hours for a response.

## Additional context
None

items.title: Installation Error: AV_OPT_TYPE_BOOL undeclared
items.body:
**I already found an alternative solution for myself (see below), but it might be worth looking into it for you.
You can close it if you don't want to investigate further.**

## Overview

When Installing via pip, gcc fails with the error message below.

## Expected behavior

I expected an successful installation.


## Actual behavior

I am using the following docker file to install av. The Error occurs in Step 3.

```
FROM pytorch/pytorch:1.3-cuda10.1-cudnn7-runtime
RUN apt update && apt install -y ffmpeg python-dev pkg-config \
    libavformat-dev libavcodec-dev libavdevice-dev \
    libavutil-dev libswscale-dev libswresample-dev libavfilter-dev
RUN pip install av
```

Build report:
```
src/av/option.c: In function '__pyx_pymod_exec_option':
    src/av/option.c:5071:51: error: 'AV_OPT_TYPE_BOOL' undeclared (first use in this function)
       __pyx_t_2 = __Pyx_PyInt_From_enum__AVOptionType(AV_OPT_TYPE_BOOL); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_2)) __PYX_ERR(0, 37, __pyx_L1_error)
                                                       ^
    src/av/option.c:5071:51: note: each undeclared identifier is reported only once for each function it appears in
    error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1
    ----------------------------------------
ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1: /opt/conda/bin/python -u -c 'import sys, setuptools, tokenize; sys.argv[0] = '"'"'/tmp/pip-install-6skfy4l1/av/setup.py'"'"'; __file__='"'"'/tmp/pip-install-6skfy4l1/av/setup.py'"'"';f=getattr(tokenize, '"'"'open'"'"', open)(__file__);code=f.read().replace('"'"'\r\n'"'"', '"'"'\n'"'"');f.close();exec(compile(code, __file__, '"'"'exec'"'"'))' install --record /tmp/pip-record-hm9xw0kn/install-record.txt --single-version-externally-managed --compile Check the logs for full command output.
The command '/bin/sh -c pip install av' returned a non-zero code: 1
```
[Full Output here](https://gist.github.com/AlexanderMelde/83a1babb9a434b3fe7eace3bc5adebaa)

## Investigation

I isolated the problem by creating a dockerfile with minimum clutter.

## Reproduction
Save above Dockerfile to a folder and run `docker build .`
Use the following command to enter the last successfull build step: `docker run -it --entrypoint bash 2c97c1ad5061` (you need to change the docker image id according to your console output)

## Versions

- OS: Ubuntu 18.04 on host / 16.04.1 inside container
- PyAV runtime: Not installed
- PyAV build: pip 7.0.1
- FFmpeg: 2.8.15
```
ffmpeg version 2.8.15-0ubuntu0.16.04.1 Copyright (c) 2000-2018 the FFmpeg developers
built with gcc 5.4.0 (Ubuntu 5.4.0-6ubuntu1~16.04.10) 20160609

libavutil      54. 31.100 / 54. 31.100

libavformat    56. 40.101 / 56. 40.101

libswscale      3.  1.101 /  3.  1.101
libswresample   1.  2.101 /  1.  2.101
libpostproc    53.  3.100 / 53.  3.1
```
- GCC: 5.4.0
```
Using built-in specs.

gcc version 5.4.0 20160609 (Ubuntu 5.4.0-6ubuntu1~16.04.11)
```

## Research

I have done the following:

- [x] Checked the [PyAV documentation](http://docs.mikeboers.com/pyav/stable/)
- [x] Searched on [Google](https://www.google.com/search?q=av+error%3A+%27AV_OPT_TYPE_BOOL%27+undeclared&oq=av+error%3A+%27AV_OPT_TYPE_BOOL%27+undeclared&aqs=chrome..69i57.4262j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8)
- [x] Searched on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/search?q=pyav+AV_OPT_TYPE_BOOL)
- [x] Looked through [old GitHub issues](https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/issues?&q=is%3Aissue)
- [ ] Asked on [PyAV Gitter](https://gitter.im/mikeboers/PyAV)
- [ ] ... and waited 72 hours for a response.

## Solution
remove `ffmpeg` from the manual apt install command and use `RUN conda install av -c conda-forge`, which successfully installs PyAV:

```

```

items.title: Install documentation has incorrect git clone URL
items.body: Nevermind! I wasn't thinking.

items.title: source contains images with embedded non-free ICC profile
items.body:
Hi,

These two images contain an ICC profile owned by Hewlett Packard and not freely licensed:
docs/_static/favicon.png
docs/_static/logo-250.png

Please strip the ICC profile from those images, (if nothing else then) to ease redistribution.

Hint (because it has become an FAQ): A tool that can detect such layered metadata is command-line tool `exiftool`, on Debian-basd systems shipped in the package `libimage-exiftool-perl` and alternatively had with the command `cpanm Image::ExifTool`.

Thanks for considering.

items.title: please tag releases
items.body:
Newest release on PyPI is 7.0.1 whereas newest git tag is v6.2.0.

Tagging in git aids those (like me, for Debian) who wants to redistribute this project and want to keep track of not only the released tarball but also correlate that with git development.

Thanks for considering.

items.title: How do I saved audio into 10 second chunks?
items.body:
**IMPORTANT:** Be sure to replace all template sections {{ like this }} or your issue may be discarded.


## Overview

I want to process audio poritions of streams through a transcription service and it only accepts 10 second chunks. How do I save the audio into <audio-001...audio-999.mp3) etc?

## Expected behavior

This is the code I have from the sample posted on this forum, how do I detect the 10 second interval within the audio frame?

```
import av
  
input_container = av.open(
    'http://184.72.239.149/vod/smil:BigBuckBunny.smil/playlist.m3u8')
input_stream = input_container.streams.get(audio=0)[0]

output_container = av.open('live_stream.mp3', 'w')
output_stream = output_container.add_stream('mp3')

for frame in input_container.decode(input_stream):
    frame.pts = None
    for packet in output_stream.encode(frame):
        output_container.mux(packet)

for packet in output_stream.encode(None):
    output_container.mux(packet)

output_container.close()
```

## Investigation

Unfortunately new to pyav and could use some starter help.

## Research

I have done the following:

- [ ] Checked the [PyAV documentation](http://docs.mikeboers.com/pyav/stable/)
- [x ] Searched on [Google](https://www.google.com/search?q=pyav+how+do+I+foo)
- [ x] Searched on [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/search?q=pyav)
- [ ] Looked through [old GitHub issues](https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/issues?&q=is%3Aissue)
- [ ] Asked on [PyAV Gitter](https://gitter.im/mikeboers/PyAV)
- [ ] ... and waited 72 hours for a response.


## Additional context

items.title: An exception occured during compiling
items.body:
**Environment:**

Windows10 x64

Python 3.5.0

The versions of pip and setuptools are the latest.

FFmpeg-4.0-x64 shared and dev ("\bin" has already insert into PATH)

All libraries in requirements.txt were installed. 

**Installation:**

Library: av-7.0.0 (Other versions also tried)

**Tried Method:**

1. PyPI

`pip install av==7.0.0`

2. setuptools

`python setup.py build --ffmpeg-dir=D:\ffmpeg`

**Exception Occured:**

Two method returned the same error.

```
...（leave out）
running cythonize
building 'av.buffer' extension
error: [WinError 2] The system cannot find the file or directory specified.
```

items.title: Error while installing av 7.0.0 using pip

items.title: to_ndarray gives array of correct shape but filled only with 0's for a rgb format frame after covration using to_rgb()
items.body:
So I have made some sample code that shows the problem (see below).
it is taken from the cython code given here (it is just easier to debug).
You will need to load av and numpy as well as change the video_path variable to any random video you have to hand (I have tried it with a few videos).
Otherwise running the code should give you "b" array with is a fine "yuv420" format of the first frame and "a" witch, if you get the same error as me, should be an "rgb" format of the same frame but ends up giving an array of the correct shape but filled only with 0's

I have tried this code on different machines and with different videos.
As far as I can see it is likely an issue with the np.frombuffer() or more particle the plane that is given to it.
I am using numpy ==1.18.1 but I have tried it with a few versions and it is the same thing making me think it is the VideoPlane give to it.
I was thinking it might be the to_rgb method but I tested that and found that the image was fine after the format change.

`def useful_array(plane,bytes_per_pixel=1,rgb=None):
    """
    Return the useful part of the VideoPlane as a single dimensional array.
    We are simply discarding any padding which was added for alignment.
    """
    import numpy as np
    total_line_size = abs(plane.line_size)
    useful_line_size = plane.width * bytes_per_pixel
    #if rgb==None:
    arr = np.frombuffer(plane, dtype=np.uint8)
    #else:
    #    arr = np.frombuffer('RGB',plane, dtype=np.uint8)
    if total_line_size != useful_line_size:
        arr = arr.reshape(-1, total_line_size)[:, 0:useful_line_size].reshape(-1)
    return arr

`def to_ndarray_try(frame):
    """Get a numpy array of this frame.
    Any ``**kwargs`` are passed to :meth:`.VideoReformatter.reformat`.
    .. note:: Numpy must be installed.
    """
    #cdef
    #VideoFrame
    #frame = self.reformat(**kwargs)

    import numpy as np

    if frame.format.name == 'yuv420p':
        assert frame.width % 2 == 0
        assert frame.height % 2 == 0
        return np.hstack((
            useful_array(frame.planes[0]),
            useful_array(frame.planes[1]),
            useful_array(frame.planes[2])
        )).reshape(-1, frame.width)
    elif frame.format.name == 'yuyv422':
        assert frame.width % 2 == 0
        assert frame.height % 2 == 0
        return useful_array(frame.planes[0], 2).reshape(frame.height, frame.width, -1)
    elif frame.format.name in ('rgb24', 'bgr24'):
        return useful_array(frame.planes[0], 3).reshape(frame.height, frame.width, -1)
    elif frame.format.name in ('argb', 'rgba', 'abgr', 'bgra'):
        return useful_array(frame.planes[0], 4).reshape(frame.height, frame.width, -1)
    elif frame.format.name in ('gray', 'gray8'):
        return useful_array(frame.planes[0]).reshape(frame.height, frame.width)
    else:
        raise ValueError('Conversion to numpy array with format `%s` is not yet supported' % frame.format.name)`


`def test_main():
    import av
    video_path = '/home/tim/Downloads/Shooting054_x264.mp4' #'/media/peter/Maxtor/UCF_Crimes/Videos/Vandalism/Vandalism048_x264.mp4'
    container = av.open(video_path,metadata_errors='ignore')
    frames_y = []
    frames_r = []
    for frame in container.decode(**{'video': 0}):
        frame_rgb = frame.to_rgb()
        frames_r.append(frame_rgb)
        frames_y.append(frame)

    b_p=frames_y[0].planes
    a_p=frames_r[0].planes

    print(type(b_p))
    print(type(a_p))

    b = to_ndarray_try(frames_y[0])
    a = to_ndarray_try(frames_r[0])
    print("worked")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    test_main()`


## Versions

- OS ubuntu 18.0.4
- ffmpeg - 4.0.1
 numpy ==1.18.1
```
PyAV v6.2.0

items.title: outcontainer unicodeencodeerror
items.body:
**IMPORTANT:** Be sure to replace all template sections {{ like this }} or your issue may be discarded.


## Overview

the out file path contain chinese character, it report  unicodeencodeerror


I have fix the bug. But I don't know how to sumbit a PR

`
 
        diff --git a/av/container/output.pyx b/av/container/output.pyx
        index 8781958..daefd1c 100644
        --- a/av/container/output.pyx
        +++ b/av/container/output.pyx
        @@ -1,5 +1,6 @@
        from fractions import Fraction
        import logging
        +import sys

        from av.codec.codec cimport Codec
        from av.container.streams cimport StreamContainer
        @@ -11,6 +12,14 @@ from av.utils cimport dict_to_avdict

        from av.dictionary import Dictionary

        +try:
        +    from os import fsencode
        +except ImportError:
        +    _fsencoding = sys.getfilesystemencoding()
        +
        +    def fsencode(s):
        +        return s.encode(_fsencoding)
        +

        log = logging.getLogger(__name__)

        @@ -162,7 +171,9 @@ cdef class OutputContainer(Container):
                    stream._finalize_for_output()

                # Open the output file, if needed.
        -        cdef char *name = "" if self.file is not None else self.name
        +        file_name = "" if self.file is not None else self.name
        +        cdef bytes name_obj = fsencode(file_name) if isinstance(file_name, unicode) else file_name
        +        cdef char *name = name_obj
                if self.ptr.pb == NULL and not self.ptr.oformat.flags & lib.AVFMT_NOFILE:
                    err_check(lib.avio_open(&self.ptr.pb, name, lib.AVIO_FLAG_WRITE))

`

items.title: Performance of the frame conversion to PIL.Image
items.body:
Hello! I found out the difference in the performance of different ways of frame conversion to PIL image. For example, I want to convert frame to PIL image and I can do it like this:
```        
for packet in cap.demux(video_stream):
            for frame in packet.decode():
                img = frame.to_rgb().to_ndarray()
                img = Image.fromarray(img)
```
Another way is to use to_image function:
```        
for packet in cap.demux(video_stream):
            for frame in packet.decode():
                img = frame.to_image()
```
I tried to extract 300 frames from video and the first script took ~1.25s, while the second took ~1.80s. Am I missing something? 
I have:
```
 av 7.0.0.dev0 version (build from commit 90e334f)
ffmpeg version n4.2
numpy                         1.18.1
Pillow                        7.0.0
```

items.title: Encoding with PyAV results in missing frames
items.body:
## Overview

I have a monochrome numpy array. Encoding with PyAV results in missing frames.

Traceback:
No exceptions

## Investigation

Tried encoding same numpy array with Moviepy using same codec. No missing frames.


## Reproduction

file: (1.4GB): https://nix-science.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/f2_e1_FishVR.mat

`hdf5_to_video --codec libx265 f2_e1_FishVR.mat  "/gROI"` results in 22 missing frames.

`hdf5_to_video --codec libx264 f2_e1_FishVR.mat  "/gROI"` results in 31 missing frames.

`hdf5_to_video --codec libx264 --moviepy f2_e1_FishVR.mat  "/gROI"` results in 0 missing frames.

hdf5_to_video:
```python
import h5py, click, os, numpy as np
from tqdm import tqdm


CONTEXT_SETTINGS = dict(help_option_names=['-h', '--help'])

@click.command(context_settings=CONTEXT_SETTINGS)
@click.argument("hdf5_file", type=click.Path(exists=True))
@click.argument("dataset", type=str)
@click.argument("output_path", type=click.Path(exists=False), required=False)
@click.option("-r", "--frame-rate", default=60, type=float, help="Hz")
@click.option('-f', '--pix-format', default='gray8', help="pixel format")
# @click.option('-b', '--bitrate', type=int, default=8000000)
@click.option('-c', '--codec', default='libx265')
@click.option('-q', '--quality', default='22', type=str, help="CRF quality")
@click.option("--av", "lib", flag_value="av", default=True)
@click.option("--moviepy", "lib", flag_value="moviepy")
def hdf5_to_video(hdf5_file: str, dataset: str, quality: str, codec, pix_format,
                          output_path: str, frame_rate: float, lib: float):
    """Convert HDF5_FILE["DATASET"] to [output_path], an .mp4 file.
    
    Dataset must be 3D tensor. Example: 
    ~/code/babelfish/scripts/hdf5_to_video f2_e1_FishVR.mat  "/gROI"
    """
    if hdf5_file is None or dataset is None:
        # print help and exit
        ctx = click.get_current_context()
        click.echo(ctx.get_help())
        exit(0)
    
    if output_path is None:
        name, _ = os.path.splitext(hdf5_file)
        name, _ = os.path.splitext(name)
        output_path = name + ".mp4"
    # scripts/hdf5_to_video /data/dlab/zfish_2p/20191101_6f/f2_e1_FishVR.mat "/gROI" x264 benchmark at 205.88 it/s
    # x265 at 110.8 it/s
    with h5py.File(hdf5_file, 'r', swmr=True) as h5:
        imaging = h5[dataset]
        print(f"found {imaging.shape[0]} frames")
        assert len(imaging.shape)==4
        assert imaging.shape[1]==1 # empty dim
        
        if lib=="av":
            import av
            output = av.open(output_path, 'w')
            stream = output.add_stream(codec, frame_rate)
            # stream.bit_rate = bitrate
            stream.pix_fmt = pix_format
            stream.options = {'crf': quality}

            for array in tqdm(imaging):
                frame = av.VideoFrame.from_ndarray(array[0], format='gray8')
                packet = stream.encode(frame)
                output.mux(packet)
            
            output.close()
            
        elif lib=="moviepy":
            import moviepy.editor as mpy
            global c
            c = 0
            print("imaging", imaging.shape)
            def make_frame(t):
                global c
                frame = np.repeat(np.array(imaging[c,0])[:,:,None],3,axis=2)
                c += 1
                return frame 
            fps = 60
            duration = len(imaging)/fps
            clip = mpy.VideoClip(make_frame, duration = duration)

            clip.write_videofile(output_path, fps=fps, codec=codec,
                ffmpeg_params=['-crf', quality])
    
    print("created video at " + output_path)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    hdf5_to_video()
```

count_vid_frames (e.g. `./count_vid_frames f2_e1_FishVR_x265.mp4`):
```python
import av, click, moviepy.editor as mpy

CONTEXT_SETTINGS = dict(help_option_names=['-h', '--help'])

@click.command(context_settings=CONTEXT_SETTINGS)
@click.argument("mp4_file", type=click.Path(exists=True))
@click.option("--av", "lib", flag_value="av", default=True)
@click.option("--moviepy", "lib", flag_value="moviepy")
def main(mp4_file: str, lib: str):
    """Count frames of .mp4"""
    if mp4_file is None:
        # print help and exit
        ctx = click.get_current_context()
        click.echo(ctx.get_help())
        exit(0)
    
    frame_count = 0

    if lib=="av":
        container = av.open(mp4_file)
        for _ in container.decode(video=0):
            frame_count += 1
    elif lib=="moviepy":    
        myclip = mpy.VideoFileClip(mp4_file)
        for _ in myclip.iter_frames():
            frame_count += 1
        
    print(f"number of frames: {frame_count}")

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

- OS: Linux
- PyAV runtime: 6.2.0

items.title: Allow nvenc encoders
items.body:
## Overview

[NVENC is more than twice as fast as cpu encoding at similar or higher quality](https://devblogs.nvidia.com/turing-h264-video-encoding-speed-and-quality/). 


## Existing FFmpeg API

https://ffmpeg.org/doxygen/trunk/structNvencContext.html


## Expected PyAV API

PyAV should support `h264_nvenc` and `nvenc_hevc` for codec options

items.title: Remove shims
items.body:
See #587.

We no longer appear to need those shims. So remove them, and it might be possible that we can ship wheels.

items.title: Provide wheels on PyPI
items.body:
You should provide pre-build wheels of PyAV on PyPI.

Currently, if you want to use PyAV, you need to compile it manually. This can cost quite a lot of time, and on Windows, you have to install VS Build Tools which are very heavy (more than 5 GB). This makes it quite hard to install and use PyAV.

You should provide pre-built wheels for all supported Python versions and systems on PyPI. You should use CI to automatically build and publish them.

items.title: The timeout setting on av.open() doesn't work as expected (for RTSP streams)
items.body:
## Overview

When I connect to my rtsp camera with a given timeout (e.g. 3s), the call to `av.open()` blocks indefinitely if the camera accepts the connection but doesn't start streaming


## Expected behavior

After the timeout expires (e.g. 3s) the function call should return with an error/exception


## Actual behavior

The call to `av.open()` hangs indefinitely and I have to `kill -s 9 python` to stop the process.


## Investigation

My RTSP camera only accepts 3 simultaneous clients receiving the stream. If (by accident) a 4th client attempts to connect, it will successfully communicate with the camera, but no stream is sent, which (after adding some logs on `av/container/core.pyx`) causes line 234 (`self.set_timeout(None)`) to clear the timeout and therefore the call to `av.open` hangs forever.  
By commenting out line 234 (not sure why the timeout is cleared anyway or where the execution hangs after line 234 to cause that infinite block), `av.open` successfully returns after the specified timeout if it wasn't able to open. In my case, it actually outputs some nice error messages:
```
Could not find codec parameters for stream 0 (Video: h264, none): unspecified size
Consider increasing the value for the 'analyzeduration' and 'probesize' options
```

[//]: # (## Reproduction)

[//]: # ({{ Steps to reproduce the behavior. If the problem is media specific, include a link to it. Only send media that you have the rights to. }})


## Versions

- OS: Ubuntu 18.04 (on docker image)
- PyAV runtime:

items.title: Decoding raw H264 frame from subprocess stdout
items.body:
## Overview

I have been working to get PyAV to decode raw h264 output from adb(android debug bridge) + screenrecord open as a python subprocess. This code is meant to be used to stream android screen and it's is based on the fallowing ffmpeg command:

`adb exec-out screenrecord --output-format h264 --size 640x310 - | ffmpeg -i - -f sdl -`

The fallowing python code was used. The main idea is to read Popen stdout and provide to pyAV decode the h264 frame. 

```
import av
import subprocess as sp
import logging


adbCmd = ['adb', 'exec-out', 'screenrecord', '--output-format=h264', '-']
stream = sp.Popen(adbCmd, stdout = sp.PIPE, universal_newlines = True, errors='replace')

class H264Decoder:
    def __init__(self):
        self.codec = av.CodecContext.create("h264", "r")

    def decode(self, encoded_frame):
        try:
            packet = av.Packet(encoded_frame)
            # packet.pts = encoded_frame.timestamp
            packet.time_base = VIDEO_TIME_BASE
            frames = self.codec.decode(packet)
        except av.AVError as e:
            logger.warning("failed to decode, skipping package: " + str(e))
            return []

        return frames


while True:
  line = stream.stdout.readline(4096)
  decoder = H264Decoder()
  decoder.decode(u' '.join(line).encode('utf-8').strip())
  if not line:
    break
```

## Actual behavior

Traceback:
```
No start code is found.
Error splitting the input into NAL units.
failed to decode, skipping package: [Errno 1094995529] Invalid data found when processing input (16: h264)
line
```


## Investigation

I got this code working using c++ and libavcodec, where the main idea is to decode raw h264 output from adb subprocess and save each frame as ppg image.
  [gist.github.com/fabriciopk/6f583f079bd929ccc708aa3d3cb37b59 ](url)

items.title: Allow different interpolation to VideoFrame.reformat
items.body:
## Overview

There is no way to scale a video frame with other interpolation methods.
`SWS_BILINEAR` is the best fit as a default, but for speed you would want `SWS_FAST_BILINEAR`, and `SWS_POINT`(neighbor) for up-scaling small frames (64x64) to better visualize them and keeping the information clean.

Using OpenCV would be an option but there are too many hoops to jump through. It's way faster to do in the native libav API.


## Desired Behavior

Ability to use different interpolation for resizing a video frame. Right now it's hardcoded to use `SWS_BILINEAR` 


## Example API

```python
frame.reformat(width=width,
               height=height,
               interpolation='neighbor')
# or maybe even better
frame.reformat(width=width,
               height=height,
               interpolation=av.video.interpolation.NEIGHBOR)
```


## Additional context

Location of hardcoded flags:
https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/blob/ae64e1ba52bea3cb72cfec473233f5137d0c1bda/av/video/frame.pyx#L200-L212

items.title: Allow automatically rotating video based on file metadata
items.body:
First of all, I would like to thank you for this fantastic library for manipulating videos in Python:)

## Overview

Here is my situation: I have developed a REST-ful API to wrap a trained video model, and I need to make sure that all uploaded videos are not rotated before I extract frames from it.

`FFmpeg` executable support automatically re-rotating video based on file metadata, it was enabled by default, but I don't know how to enable this feature in `PyAV`. 

You can find this feature from `FFmpeg` [document](https://ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg.html):

```
-noautorotate
    Disable automatically rotating video based on file metadata.
```

I'm not sure this feature implemented in FFmpeg executable or library, I also tried to search in `PyAV` documents and issues, but nobody mentions this.

## Existing FFmpeg API

In [https://ffmpeg.org/doxygen/trunk/ffplay_8c_source.html#l00355](https://ffmpeg.org/doxygen/trunk/ffplay_8c_source.html#l00355):

```c
static int autorotate = 1;
```

## Expected PyAV API

Allow user set option like `autorotate` when calling `av.open`, next time `container.decode(video=0)` called the video frame would be auto-rotated by video metadata.

Example:
```
container = av.open('VIDEO_PATH', autorotate=True)
```


## Investigation

Search document in PyAV and FFmpeg, dig into FFmpeg code.


## Reproduction



## Versions

- OS:  Ubuntu 16.04.5 LTS
- PyAV runtime:
```

```

- PyAV build:
```
{{ Complete output of `python setup.py config --verbose`. }}
```

- FFmpeg:

ffmpeg version 3.2 Copyright (c) 2000-2016 the FFmpeg developers

items.title: Make err_check raise OSError when appropriate?
items.body:
FFmpeg functions will return standard error codes sometimes. They are currently being raised as AVError, but perhaps they should be OSError instead.

Options:

1. Leave them as `AVError`.
2. Raise `OSError` when the codes are known to `errno` module. I vaguely like this one best, even though it likely breaks more code.
3. Make a new `AVOSError` which extends from `AVError` and `OSError`, and raise that. This would still let you catch them separately, but old code wouldn't break (although new code would have to do them in the right order).

items.title: Unify flags interface.
items.body:
Looking at #474 and the recent exposing of `Stream.flags` and `Stream.flags2` for motion vectors, I'd like to consider unifying how we expose flags. The options:

1. An object which represents all of the flags, which can work with string and integer values, e.g.:
```
stream.flags2.export_mvs
'export_mvs' in stream.flags2 # assuming it is set-like instead of dict-like
stream.flags2 |= 16
```

2. An object which represents all of the flags, but can't work with integer values, e.g.:
```
stream.flags.export_mvs = True # this is normally flags2!
'export_mvs' in stream.flags
```

3. Properties for each flag, e.g.:
```
stream.export_mvs
```

Option 3 feels more "Pythonic", but clutters up the API a lot. Option 2 feels like an okay middle ground, as we can still lean on the FFmpeg docs for a lot.

Thoughts?

items.title: Drop support FFmpeg < 4.0
items.body:
All of the `3.x` releases were more than 2 years ago.

All of the conda FFmpeg's are now `4.2` (except for `win32`, where we are hilariously behind as well).

Time to cut them off?

items.title: Encoding issue at the beginning of videos when using libx264
items.body:
The first few frames of an encoded video seem to have errors when using libx264.  It does not seem to be the case when using mpeg4.

![encoding-issues](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/197069/64234198-19b3c800-cef6-11e9-88c2-d21290c23355.png)

Example code

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import numpy
import av
import cv2

#--------------------------------------------------------------------

def bounce(p, r, s, mn, mx):
    return (0 < s and (p + r + s) > mx) or (0 > s and mn > (p - r + s))

def createVideo():

    # Video
    w = 640
    h = 480
    fps = 30
    brate = 100000
    duration = 10

    # Output file name
    outfile = './ball.mp4'

    # Ball speed
    xs = 10
    ys = 10

    # Ball size
    sz = 20

    # Initial position
    x = int(w / 2)
    y = int(h / 2)

    # Audio sample rate, 8000, 44100, 48000
    asr = 48000

    # Time base
    time_base = asr

    # Attempt to create a video writer
    avf = av.open(file=outfile, format=None, mode="w", options={})
    if not avf:
        print("!! Failed to create video file : " + outfile)
        return

    # Add video stream
    vstream = avf.add_stream("libx264", rate=fps)
#    vstream = avf.add_stream("mpeg4", rate=fps)
    vstream.pix_fmt = "yuv420p"
    vstream.width = w
    vstream.height = h
    vstream.bit_rate = brate
    vstream.bit_rate_tolerance = int(brate / 10)
    vstream.time_base = "1/" + str(time_base)

    # Add audio stream
    astream = avf.add_stream("aac", rate=asr, layout='stereo')
    astream.time_base = "1/" + str(time_base)

    # Create a blank image
    arr = numpy.zeros([h,w,3], dtype=numpy.uint8)

    # Number of audio samples per interval
    nsamples = int(asr / fps)

    # Create silence
    silence = numpy.zeros((2, nsamples), dtype='int16')

    # Create bouncy sound
    bouncymono = (30000 * numpy.sin(2 * numpy.pi * numpy.arange(nsamples) * 440 / asr)).astype(numpy.int16)
    att = int(nsamples / 3)
    for i in range(0, att):
        bouncymono[i] = (i/att) * bouncymono[i]
        bouncymono[nsamples - i - 1] = (i/att) * bouncymono[nsamples - i - 1]

    # Stereo bouncy sound
    bouncysound = numpy.array([bouncymono, bouncymono])

    # Write frames to file
    for i in range(0, duration * fps):

        bounced = False

        # Update X position
        if bounce(x, sz, xs, 0, w):
            bounced = True
            xs = -xs
        x += xs

        # Update Y position
        if bounce(y, sz, ys, 0, h):
            bounced = True
            ys = -ys
        y += ys
        
        # Draw the ball
        cv2.rectangle(arr, (0, 0), (w, h), (0, 0, 0), -1)
        cv2.circle(arr, (x, y), sz, (255, 0, 0, 0), -1)

        # Write video frame
        frame = av.VideoFrame.from_ndarray(arr, format='rgb24')
        frame.pts = int(i * time_base / fps) 
        frame.time_base = '1/' + str(time_base)
        for packet in vstream.encode(frame):
            avf.mux(packet)

        # Bouncy sound?
        atrack = bouncysound if bounced else silence

        # Write audio
        aframe = av.AudioFrame.from_ndarray(atrack, 's16p')
        aframe.pts = int(i * time_base / fps) 
        aframe.sample_rate = asr
        aframe.time_base = '1/' + str(time_base)
        for packet in astream.encode(aframe):
            avf.mux(packet)

    # Finalize
    for packet in vstream.encode():
        avf.mux(packet)
    for packet in astream.encode():
        avf.mux(packet)

    # Close the file
    avf.close()
    avf = None


if __name__ == '__main__':
    createVideo()
```

items.title: Regression: decoding webm audio inserts spurious bytes in recent versions of pyav
items.body:
Hello, 

In pyav version 0.3.3 (I realize this is old), linked against debian-8 libav libraries (libavcodec56, libavformat56, I realize this is really, really old) we can correctly decode/resample webm audio (as it is sent by chrome and firefox), using the boilerplate code 
```python
#!/usr/bin/env python

import av
import logging

logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

def use_packet():
    container = av.open("in.webm", format="webm")
    resampler = av.AudioResampler(
        format=av.AudioFormat("s16p").packed,
        layout=int(1),
        rate=16000,
    )
    out = open("out.raw", "wb")
    audio = container.streams[0]
    for packet in container.demux(audio):
        logger.debug("packet %r", packet)
        if not packet:
            break
        try:
            for frame in packet.decode():
                frame.pts = None
                frame = resampler.resample(frame)
                logger.debug("frame %r", frame)
                for i, plane in enumerate(frame.planes):
                    logger.debug("plane %d %r", i, plane)
                    bytes = plane.to_bytes()
                    out.write(bytes)
        except Exception as e:
            print('Error', e, 'data', packet)
    out.close()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    use_packet()
```
However, in a more recent environment (pyav 6.2.0, ffmpeg 3.2, with libavcodec.so.57 libavformat.so.57) the decoded output contains blocks of spurious bytes, audible as regular loud clicks.  The output also does not seem to reproduce from one invocation to another.

The correct output file size is 94700 bytes, the incorrect output files size is 96032 bytes. 

Decoding using the same ffmpeg 3.2 command line tools `ffmpeg -i in.webm -ar 16000 out.wav` works fine.  

It is possible that the above boilerplate code is incorrect, specifically, I had to add the line `frame.pts = None` for the more recent pyav version, but I don't know if that is appropriate here. 

I've attached a zip that contains the `in.webm` file (github doesn't accept all file types).  

[in.zip](https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/files/3392118/in.zip)

def convert(input, output, filename, codec, channel_layout, frame_rate):

    # set input/output locations

    out = av.open(f"{output}\\{filename}", 'w')
    out_stream = out.add_stream(f"{codec}")

        rate=frame_rate

    # decode frames and start re-encoding into new file
    for frame in inp.decode(audio=0):
        frame.pts = None  # pts is presentation time-stamp. Not relevant here.

        frame = resampler.resample(frame)  # get current working frame and re-sample it for encoding

items.title: Color values and dimensions read from frame are wrong?
items.body:
I am generating two videos, one all white, one all black, using libx264 with a yuv420 pixel format:

```
ffmpeg -f lavfi -i color=color=black:d=1:s=32x32 black.mp4
ffmpeg -f lavfi -i color=color=white:d=1:s=32x32 white.mp4
```

I want to read the pixel values from the luma plane only. So I do:

```python
#!/usr/bin/env python3
import numpy as np
import av
import sys

input_file = sys.argv[1]
container = av.open(input_file)
for packet in container.demux():
    for frame in packet.decode():
        if isinstance(frame, av.video.frame.VideoFrame):
            frame_data_raw = np.frombuffer(frame.planes[0], np.uint8)
            print(np.mean(frame_data_raw))
            sys.exit(1)
```

This is what I get:

```
➜ ./test_av.py black.mp4
4.0
➜ ./test_av.py white.mp4
58.75
```

Surely, this cannot be right. I would expect the average value for the black video to be 0, and the average value for the white video to be 255.

When I inspect the data returned, I see:

```
> np.shape(frame_data_raw)
(4096,)
```

But the video is 32⨉32, so that should be 1024. In fact, there are some values as 0, and some as 16, as if there was extra data in the plane. What am I doing wrong here?

NB, with scikit-video, I am getting the correct results:

```python
import numpy as np
import skvideo.io
import sys
for frame in skvideo.io.vreader(sys.argv[1], as_grey=True):
    width = frame.shape[-2]
    height = frame.shape[-3]
    frame_data_raw = frame.reshape((height, width))
    print(np.mean(frame_data_raw))
```

This gives `0.0` and `255.0`, as expected.

items.title: Make AudioFrame / VideoFrame more gc-friendly
items.body:
@Mofef pointed out in https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/issues/317#issuecomment-467893423 that our `VideoFrame` contain reference cycles which prevent the garbage collector from reclaiming the frames as soon as they are unused. Let's try and improve this!

Here is a trivial example which currently has a fairly large memory (but stable) memory consumption:

```python
import av
  
with av.open('test.mp4') as container:
    for frame in container.decode(video=0):
        print(frame.pts)
```

On a 1080p video, RSS stabilizes around 480MB for me.

        # input

            # exit and flushing

                while True:

items.title: frame pts is zero
items.body:
I'm having a strange issue with frames I read from an av.container. It doesn't seem to happen with ffprobe on the command line. The issue is that the frame.pts and frame.time values are zero for more than half of the frames. I get bursts of 20-40 frames with proper timestamps, then at least that number of zeros, often more. Here's a script that demonstrates it:

```
import av

if __name__ == '__main__':
    container = av.open(file='/dev/video0',
                        format='v4l2',
                        mode='r',
                        options={'video_size':'320x240'})

    while(True):
        frame = next(container.decode())
        print(frame.pts)
```

Running this, I get output like this (edited for brevity):

```
aiortc_py3) pi@raspberrypi:~/projects/av_issue $ python frames.py 
325219215
325352522
325385849
325419176
...
[_CONTINUES LIKE THIS FOR 20 OR SO FRAMES_]
...
326418981
0
0
0
...
[_NOTHING BUT ZEROS FOR 40 FRAMES OR SO_]
...
0
0
327985339
328018666
328051993
328085320
328118647
328151973
328185302
328218628
328251954
```

This pattern seems to repeat itself indefinitely. There's some variation in the amount of good vs bad frames, but not much. 

I also tried saving the frames as images and checked them - they look fine, so it seems to be just the times that are a problem. 

I know pyav gets the frame data from ffmpeg, but when I run ffprobe to check the frames like this:

`pi@raspberrypi:~/projects/av_issue $ /usr/bin/ffprobe -i /dev/video0 -show_frames | grep pkt_pts=
`

...then all the timestamps look fine - no zeros. 

Could there be something in the way I'm calling open(...) that's causing an issue? I'd like to see what other "options" are available, but I can't find any documentation for this. Can you point me towards anything?

I'm using a raspberry pi with the bcm2835-v4l2 camera driver, and pyav 6.1.2. 

ffmpeg version is 3.2.12-1. I've built a newer one from the latest source, but don't know how to make pyyav use that one instead. But since this version seems to get the frames correctly on the command line, I'm not sure if that's the best direction to look. 

Can you give me any suggestions for further debugging? Thanks!

items.title: av.read() exit gracefully on corrupt files?
items.body:
I'm trying to load some videos using `av.read` and I am aware that dataset contains corrupt files. Most corrupt files can get filtered out by a simple trycatch as

```
# minimal reproducible example
for d in input_files[7161:7163]:
    try:
        vr = av.open(d)
    except:
        print("Skipping file {} - might be corrupted".format(d))
```

however, on a several, the file crashes with 
```
Invalid NAL unit size (54396 > 13392).
Error splitting the input into NAL units.
Could not find codec parameters for stream 0 (Video: h264 (avc1 / 0x31637661), none, 640x360, 750 kb/s): unspecified pixel format
```
which is not caught in the exception, but rather completely breaks the code. 
Is there a nicer way to gracefully exit or skip files upon this error? 

I could do a binary search to find the videos in question but the dataset is quite large (2M examples) and it would take hours do do it by hand.


NOTE: trying to catch it with
```        
except av.AVError:
```
fails as well.

items.title: Cluelessness with codecs / Video-pixelation
items.body:
Hi guys, 

i have a problem in my code and i think its caused by the codec (or probably by me).


    codec = 'libx264'
    images = [img for img in os.listdir(plots_path) if img.endswith(".png")]
    images.sort()
    frame = cv2.imread(os.path.join(plots_path, images[0]))
    height, width, layers = frame.shape 


    video_name = video_path + os.path.sep + str(name) + ".mp4"

    video_file = av.open(video_name, 'w')
    stream = video_file.add_stream(codec,fps)
    stream.time_base = Fraction(1,1000)
    stream.pix_fmt = 'yuv420p'
    for i,image in enumerate(images):
        img=Image.open("plots/"+str(image))
        frame= av.VideoFrame.from_image(img)
        frame.pts=frame_time[i]
        packet = stream.encode(frame)
        video_file.mux(packet)

        os.remove(plots_path + os.path.sep + str(image))

    video_file.close()`

I will briefly describe my code: 
It will take a list of images and turn them into a video-file.
'frame_time' is an array with the specific time (in ms) at which the frame should be shown.
Therefore im setting the stream.time_base to Fraction(1,1000) that one time_base-unit should be 1ms right?
If im using some functions wrong etc. please feel free to correct me :)


But now to my problem:

When i use the codec 'mpeg4' the video will lose quality the longer it goes and at the end it will have a very pixelated quality but the video will render till the end.
But when i use the codec 'libx264' the quality will stay super sharp, but the video won't render till the end. The last 0.5 seconds won't be in the video.

I will appreciate every help i'd get and im sorry for the inconvenience.

Thanks guys


//Edit: 
i added this at the end:
`    for packet in stream.encode():
              video_file.mux(packet)`

and now the libx264 is working (the video is playing until the end).
But the mpeg4 version is still getting very pixelated (which is probably a mistake of mine?!)

Its working for me now so this thread could be closed, unless the pixelation of mpeg4 isnt my fault.

PS: Im fairly new to PyAv, so if you see ways to improve my code or give me tips in any way, im more than happy to hear it ;) 

Greets TheRedCupDude

items.title: VideoFrame.from_ndarray(img) fails for widths that are not a multiple of 8
items.body:
Any call to `VideoFrame.from_ndarray(img)` fails if the image width is not a multiple of 8.

Error message:
```
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
      5 av.VideoFrame.from_ndarray(img) # <- OK
      6 img = np.zeros((100, 100, 3), dtype=np.uint8)
----> 7 av.VideoFrame.from_ndarray(img) # <- FAILS

av/video/frame.pyx in av.video.frame.VideoFrame.from_ndarray()

av/buffer.pyx in av.buffer.Buffer.update()

ValueError: got 100 bytes; need 31200 bytes
```

Minimal code reproducing the issue:
```python
import av
import numpy as np

img = np.zeros((100, 104, 3), dtype=np.uint8)
av.VideoFrame.from_ndarray(img) # <- OK
img = np.zeros((100, 100, 3), dtype=np.uint8)
av.VideoFrame.from_ndarray(img) # <- FAILS
```

I see the error with Python 2 and 3, in particular:
- Python 2.7.13 with av 6.0.0 and FFmpeg 3.4,
- Python 3.6.4 with av 6.1.0 and FFmpeg 3.4.

Hello, 
I'm using your library to put an image sequence into mp4/h264 file. 
I'd like to use this format to be able to play the video in a web browser.
Basically I used an example here https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/blob/master/examples/encode_frames.py

Here is my code:


	import os
	import numpy as np
	import cv2
	import av


	#
	# example
	# https://github.com/mikeboers/PyAV/blob/master/examples/encode_frames.py
	#

	# fps = '29.97'
	fps = '23.976'

	# size = (640,360)

	# libx264
	codec = 'h264'
	# codec = 'x264'
	# codec = 'mpeg4'

	bitrate = 8000000
	fmt = 'yuv420p'

	def get_filename(i):
	  s = str(i)
	  while len(s) < 4:
		s = '0' + s
	  return '/app/rendering/ffd06183-226c-4320-ad46-ac0a1b03a5cf/' + s + '.png'

	output_file = '/app/rendering/ffd06183-226c-4320-ad46-ac0a1b03a5cf/output_av.mp4'
	output = av.open(output_file, 'w')

	images = [cv2.imread( get_filename(i) ) for i in range(1,35)]


	stream = output.add_stream(codec, fps)
	stream.bit_rate = bitrate
	stream.pix_fmt = fmt

	for i, img in enumerate(images):
		# print( img )

		if not i:
			stream.height = img.shape[0]
			stream.width = img.shape[1]

		frame = av.VideoFrame.from_ndarray(img, format='bgr24')
		packet = stream.encode(frame)
		output.mux(packet)

	output.close()

	print('done \n')
